A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
Does the concept of a/an Cyclic group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Order of an element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the order of an element explicitly states that it is the order of the cyclic group generated by that element in a group G. This implies that the concept of a cyclic group is integral to understanding and defining the order of an element. Without the concept of a cyclic group, one cannot define what it means for an element to generate a group or determine the smallest positive integer m such that a^m = 1, as these ideas rely on the structure and properties of cyclic groups. Therefore, the concept of a cyclic group is necessary for the definition of the order of an element to be meaningful and complete.
